questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of 4-week history of lesions on his penis and scrotum. He has no pain or discharge from the lesions. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia and was treated with imatinib. He is sexually active and had unprotected intercourse with a woman about 4 months ago while abroad on business. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He takes no medications. He appears well. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Examination shows 3 nontender lesions up to 1 cm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which also manifests with a genital lesion at the site where Treponema pallidum entered the body. Primary syphilis is characterized by a single genital lesion (chancre) that begins as a raised papule and subsequently develops into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders and a smooth base. Regional nontender lymphadenopathy is common. This patient has multiple highly vascular lesions and no lymphadenopathy.
Image Description:

A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

B) CORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which is characterized by large, painless vascular lesions in the absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy that appear up to one year after exposure. Diagnosis is based primarily on clinical findings, although Donovan bodies in ulcer smears or biopsies can confirm the diagnosis. Management focuses on antibiotic treatment with azithromycin, which is continued until the ulcers have completely healed.

Even though this patient's sexual behavior puts him at increased risk and his presentation is highly characteristic of granuloma inguinale, mixed infections and bacterial superinfection are common; therefore, he should be screened for other sexually transmitted infections such as syphilis and HIV.
Image Description:

Exudate smear (Giemsa stain)

Coccobacilli are visible as inclusion bodies within macrophages (Donovan bodies). In some cases, the characteristic safety pin shape can be seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV type 2 causes genital herpes, which typically manifests with grouped painful vesicles, pustules, and erosions on an erythematous base and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy after an incubation period of 2–7 days. The painless lesions and lack of lymphadenopathy in this patient are not consistent with genital herpes.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

D) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which may also manifest with genital lesions. However, these lesions are typically very painful and clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base. While in women multiple lesions may be present, in men, a single lesion is common. In addition, it is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, suggesting a different causal organism here.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

E) INCORRECT:

L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LV), which initially manifests as a solitary transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy (buboes) is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals and is accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, chills). This patient has multiple large, vascular ulcers, no regional lymphadenopathy, and no systemic signs, making LV unlikely.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: This patient's condition may be confirmed through the detection of Donovan bodies in ulcer smears or biopsies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. She has not had fever, chills, or abdominal pain. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is sexually active with one male partner and they do not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. There is no uterine or cervical motion tenderness. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet mount preparation of vaginal smear can be used to detect flagellated protozoa characteristic of trichomoniasis and clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). These conditions can cause malodorous vaginal discharge but typically result in an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5). In addition, isolated cervicitis is not a typical manifestation of either of these conditions. A wet mount preparation is unreliable in diagnosing the most common infectious causes of cervicitis because these infections only cause the nonspecific finding of a high leukocyte number on the wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

The amine test (whiff test) is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause malodorous vaginal discharge. However, BV typically manifests with an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5) and a gray or milky rather than mucopurulent discharge. Isolated cervicitis makes BV highly unlikely. The amine test does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine analysis and culture would be the most appropriate initial step if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. This patient presents with cervicitis and does not report features of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain).

D) CORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred modality for diagnosing Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections, which are the most common causes of cervicitis. NAAT can also diagnose certain uncommon causes of acute cervicitis such as trichomoniasis. Patients with confirmed gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichomoniasis should also be screened for HIV and syphilis. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing is indicated during the initial prenatal visit (at approx. 10 weeks' gestation) in all patients < 25 years of age and in patients ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can manifest with vaginal discharge and a normal vaginal pH of 4.0–4.5. The discharge, however, is usually odorless and white, crumbly, and sticky rather than mucopurulent. In addition, features of inflammatory vaginitis (e.g., intense pruritus, vaginal burning, dyspareunia, vulvar and vaginal erythema) are typically present. Isolated cervicitis is not typical of vulvovaginal candidiasis. A KOH preparation does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.
questions.hint: An inflamed, friable cervix with a mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os in a sexually active patient suggests cervicitis.

questions.text: An endocervical swab is performed and nucleic acid amplification testing via polymerase chain reaction is conducted. It is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used in the case of chlamydial infection but the administration of doxycycline during pregnancy is contraindicated because intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in the teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring. Although cefoxitin is effective against N. gonorrhoeae, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need cefoxitin. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for N. gonorrhea infection. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhea and positive for C. trachomatis; ceftriaxone is not the first-line therapy for C. trachomatis.

C) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is very effective against C. trachomatis but the administration of fluoroquinolones is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation due to its potential to cause bone and cartilage damage in the fetus.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin is administered for chlamydial infections in which gonococcal infection is also suspected. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need ceftriaxone. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

E) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydial infection in nonpregnant patients but is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and tooth staining in the child. A single dose of oral azithromycin is the recommended first-line treatment for chlamydial infection in pregnant patients. Expedited partner testing and therapy are also recommended to avoid reinfection. Furthermore, patients and their sexual partners should abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days after treatment initiation.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is a first-line treatment option in nonpregnant women who have an isolated chlamydial infection. Although this patient has tested positive for C. trachomatis, doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has cervicitis caused by C. trachomatis and should be treated with an antibiotic that is approved for use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 42 years. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and pelvic examinations show no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count would be required if the patient had any signs of an infection, inflammation, or anemia but is not necessary in a young individual with no symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is highly sensitive and specific for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae and is the gold standard for screening for these infections. Genital chlamydia and gonorrhea may be asymptomatic but can cause complications if left untreated (e.g., infertility, pelvic inflammatory disease). Since this patient is sexually active, it is recommended that she be screened for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae, even though she is asymptomatic.

C) INCORRECT:

The current USPSTF recommendation for cervical cancer screening is a PAP smear every 3 years beginning at 21 years of age, regardless of the initiation of sexual activity. Cervical cancer is rare in women < 21 years of age. Moreover, detection of an abnormal PAP smear in this age group (e.g., due to a cervical infection/inflammation) may lead to overtreatment (e.g., surgical excision/laser/cryotherapy of the suspicious area of the cervix), which could adversely affect future childbearing and cause unnecessary anxiety. Since this patient is 17 years of age, a PAP smear is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

In the US, vaccination against HPV is part of the routine immunization schedule. The vaccine can be administered from 9–26 years of age, but should ideally be administered between 11–12 years of age and preferably before any sexual contact to be most effective. Since the immunizations of this 17-year-old patient are up-to-date, it is highly likely that she has already received the vaccination against HPV.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) infections may be asymptomatic and this patient is at risk because of her unprotected sexual activity. However, the CDC generally reserves HSV-2 screening for high-risk groups, including HIV-positive patients, men who have sex with men, and patients recently diagnosed with an STI, none of which applies to this patient.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends chlamydia and gonorrhea screening in sexually active women < 25 years of age and in older women with risk factors for STIs.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lesion on his penis. There is no history of itching or pain associated with the lesion. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Five weeks ago, he returned from a trip to the Caribbean with some of his football teammates. He has recently started an intense exercise program. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple enlarged, nontender lymph nodes in the inguinal area bilaterally. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is a common cause of tinea cruris, which manifests with pruritus and scaly erythema of the groin and adjacent skin that may worsen with exercise rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in this patient.
Image Description:

There is a sharply demarcated, light gray lesion with a raised border and scaling around the pubic area and upper thighs.

These findings are consistent with tinea cruris.

B) INCORRECT:

While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Mycoplasma genitalium is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, symptomatic disease in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus infection commonly results in condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts). Patients present with multiple painless, cauliflower-like lesions on the penis and/or perineal region rather than the genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

D) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection that can manifest with a genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, both the genital ulcer and the lymph nodes will be severely painful, unlike the painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy seen here.
Image Description:

There is massive bilateral swelling of inguinal lymph nodes. The skin above the lymph nodes is livid. The causative agent is Haemophilus ducreyi.

E) CORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes the sexually transmitted infection syphilis. In the earliest stage of syphilis (primary syphilis), patients present with a painless papule that evolves into an ulcer with a smooth base and indurated border (chancre) at the site of inoculation, as seen here. Painless, nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance. If left untreated, the disease progresses after a period of 8–12 weeks to secondary syphilis with generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, polymorphic rash, fever, condylomata lata, and/or patchy alopecia. Finally, tertiary syphilis can cause cardiovascular manifestations (e.g., ascending aortic aneurysm) and neurosyphilis.

The presence of characteristic clinical features and positive serology raises suspicion for syphilis. Dark-field microscopy or PCR showing Treponema pallidum in exudate from the chancre confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, the patient should be offered HIV testing and screening for other sexually transmitted infections, as his syphilis infection is indicative of high-risk sexual behavior. Treatment of primary syphilis consists of a single intramuscular injection of penicillin G.

F) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 2 is a common cause of genital herpes, which can manifest with genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy. However, patients typically have multiple flat, painful erosions on an erythematous base, unlike the single painless ulcer with raised, non-inflamed margins seen here. Lymphadenopathy is usually tender, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and headache would also be expected.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

G) INCORRECT:

Serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LV), a sexually transmitted disease that can cause painless genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. LV is more common in subtropical and tropical countries, such as the Caribbean, putting this patient at increased risk. However, the ulcer is usually small and shallow and disappears by the time lymphadenopathy is apparent. Furthermore, lymphadenopathy would be quite painful, unlike the painless inguinal lymph nodes seen here. Also, patients frequently have systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, and myalgia.
Image Description:

A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).

This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

H) INCORRECT:

While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, gonorrhea in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, purulent urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

I) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted infection that is endemic in tropical and subtropical countries, such as the Caribbean. Patients may present with a painless genital ulcer, but the ulcer has a red, beefy appearance (due to the vascular nature of the lesion) and typically does not cause regional lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The lesion will evolve into an ulcer and spontaneously resolve if left untreated. However, the infection will manifest again after approximately 8 weeks with a diffuse, polymorphic, copper-colored rash involving the palms and soles.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. HPV vaccines are recommended by the CDC to all persons aged 9–26 years and are most effective before exposure to HPV via sexual activity; they are routinely administered at 11–12 years of age. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and in cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time period). Given this patient's sexual history, HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer.
Image Description:

Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms
questions.hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male comes to the physician because of painful genital sores, malaise, and fever for 3 days. He is sexually active with 3 female partners and does not use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Physical examination shows tender lymphadenopathy in the left inguinal region and multiple, punched-out ulcers over the penile shaft and glans. Microscopic examination of a smear from the ulcer is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions on a smear of an ulcer or opened vesicle describe the Cowdry A inclusion bodies seen in infections by herpesviruses such as HSV-1, HSV-2, VZV, and CMV. These intranuclear inclusions are formed during herpesvirus replication within the nucleus. Another microscopic characteristic of herpesvirus infection is the formation of multinucleated giant cells as a result of the fusion of multiple infected cells (seen on Tzanck smear). HSV-2 can remain dormant in the sacral ganglia after the primary infection to cause recurrent genital herpes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a smear from the base of a herpetic (HSV-1) gingivostomatitis lesion (Pappenheim stain; very high magnification)

A multinucleated giant cell (Tzanck cell) can be seen, indicating a positive Tzanck test.

B) INCORRECT:

Reticulate bodies, which would appear as basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions, are seen with infections by Chlamydia trachomatis. Lymphogranuloma inguinale, which is caused by C. trachomatis serotypes L1–L3, can manifest with multiple genital ulcers, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms. However, the genital ulcers in lymphogranuloma venereum would be painless. Basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (200x magnification)

The cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (example circled in blue) are identifiable by inclusion bodies (brown; example marked by hatched overlay), surrounded by a thin rim of host cytoplasm. Over the course of the pathogen's life cycle, elementary bodies (examples circled in white) are formed within the inclusion bodies. These are released from the cell and serve to transmit the pathogen to other cells or hosts.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions can be seen in infections by rhabdovirus (e.g., Negri bodies in rabies) or poxvirus (e.g., molluscum contagiosum), both of which are large viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm. Molluscum contagiosum can manifest with genital lesions, but the lesions would be flesh-colored, pearly, dome-shaped, or umbilicated papules, unlike the punched-out ulcers in this patient. Rabies is a terminal CNS disease characterized by insanity and hydrophobia, and Negri bodies would occur only in neurons. Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.

Non-infectious conditions associated with eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions include Parkinson disease (Lewy bodies), Leydig cell tumors (Reinke crystals), and alcohol-associated liver disease (Mallory bodies).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A pyramidal cell (green overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The distinct eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions within the pyramidal cells are Negri bodies (examples indicated by black arrowheads and white dashed outlines).

Negri bodies are most commonly found within the pyramidal cells of hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of patients infected by the rabies virus. Although the presence of Negri bodies is pathognomonic of rabies, their absence does not rule out infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Basophilic intranuclear inclusions can be seen, e.g., in adenovirus infections, which typically manifest with pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, pneumonia, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, gastroenteritis, or myocarditis. Basophilic intranuclear inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Bipolar-staining intracytoplasmic inclusions (Donovan bodies) would be seen in cases of granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale typically manifests as a single, painless, beefy red ulcer without lymphadenopathy or systemic signs of infection. Bipolar-staining intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.
Image Description:

Exudate smear (Giemsa stain)

Coccobacilli are visible as inclusion bodies within macrophages (Donovan bodies). In some cases, the characteristic safety pin shape can be seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, multiple punched-out ulcers, and systemic signs of infection (e.g., malaise, fever) suggest herpes genitalis, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2).

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and fluid release from painful lumps in the right groin. He had an atraumatic ulceration of the penis about 1 month ago that was not painful and resolved on its own within 1 week. He works at an animal shelter for abandoned pets. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and does not use condoms. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination of the groin shows numerous, tender nodules with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease (CSD), which can manifest with fever, general malaise, and tender, suppurative lymphadenopathy. This patient's history of working at an animal shelter puts him at risk for exposure to Bartonella henselae. However, CSD typically manifests with papules and/or pustules at the cutaneous site of inoculation, which is most commonly in the limbs. This patient's penile lesion and sexual history make a different causative pathogen more likely.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

B) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. Primary syphilis manifests with a painless, genital ulcer (chancre) and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient's lesions, the inguinal lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis is nonsuppurative, occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance, and is not accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). Moreover, the genital ulcer usually resolves within 3–6 weeks without treatment (rather than 1 week).
Image Description:

A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) can cause genital ulcers, fever, and tender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, HSV-2 usually causes multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers and nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. In contrast to this patient's initial ulcer, these lesions do not spontaneously resolve.
Image Description:

The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.

These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) CORRECT:

The serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum, the incidence of which is increased in men who have sex with men. Further manifestations include systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, chills, and/or myalgia. Lymphogranuloma venereum is treated with doxycycline or macrolides such as erythromycin. Without antibiotic treatment, lymphogranuloma venereum can cause chronic genital lymphedema, strictures in the anogenital tract, and/or infertility.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which causes painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient, who has a history of a self-resolving, painless genital ulcer, chancroid causes painful genital ulcers with yellow-gray exudates. Systemic manifestations, such as fever, are uncommon.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which can initially manifest with painless, suppurative genital lesions. However, these lesions are typically beefy-red, bleed easily (due to their hypervascularity), spread and destroy surrounding tissue, and do not resolve spontaneously without treatment. Regional lymphadenopathy and fever are generally absent, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.
questions.hint: A painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–4 weeks after the initial lesion has healed is consistent with a diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had “at least 30 sexual partners” since. Physical examination shows a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the lesion shows atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly with types 16 and 18, is a known risk factor for carcinoma of the penis. Other risk factors for carcinoma of the penis include phimosis and HIV infection. Although HIV may directly contribute to carcinogenesis, this association may also be due to the frequent HPV co-infection in this patient group. Apart from the immunosuppression enabling the persistence of HPV infection, HIV also seems to directly promote HPV-associated carcinogenesis.

High-risk types of HPV (i.e., 16, 18, 31, 33) are also associated with cervical cancer (almost all cases), as well as anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

B) INCORRECT:

EBV is associated with several malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. However, EBV is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

C) INCORRECT:

HSV-2 is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes genital herpes. Unlike this patient's slowly increasing painless ulcer, genital herpes typically manifests with multiple painful lesions that evolve from vesicles and pustules to ulcers over about 10 days. Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is common. HSV-2 is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

D) INCORRECT:

H. ducreyi is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes chancroid. Unlike this patient's presentation, chancroid typically manifests with erythematous papules that become pustular and erode into very painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. H. ducreyi is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

E) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted pathogen and a common cause of genitourinary infections such as urethritis and epididymitis. None of these infections would cause a gradually increasing ulcerated lesion on the penis. Moreover, they are associated with symptoms such as purulent urethral discharge and dysuria (if urethritis), or scrotal pain and swelling (if epididymitis). N. gonorrhoeae is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

F) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, painless ulcer in the genital region (chancre) as well as regional nontender lymphadenopathy. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals spontaneously within 3–6 weeks. Systemic symptoms due to secondary syphilis are expected 3–4 months after primary infection. T. pallidum is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

G) INCORRECT:

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted pathogen whose serotypes L1–L3 can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. This condition initially manifests with a small, painless ulcer in the genital region. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals and disappears within one week. After 2–6 weeks, the extension of the infection to the draining lymph nodes results in painful, suppurative, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). C. trachomatis is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 13 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of burning pain during urination. She has been sexually active with different male partners during the pregnancy and did not use condoms. She has not had any fever, chills, or pelvic pain. Physical examination shows thick, purulent discharge from the urethra. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase, urinalysis shows 10 WBCs/hpf, and Gram stain of the urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular gram-negative diplococci. Nucleic acid amplification testing confirms infection with a single pathogen. Pelvic ultrasound shows a viable intrauterine pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral levofloxacin is a second-line treatment option for confirmed infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Genitourinary Chlamydia infection can manifest with dysuria and urethral discharge in a sexually active patient. However, this patient's urinalysis indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, for which levofloxacin is not a recommended treatment. Moreover, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy due to possible damage to the fetal cartilage.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular penicillin G is the first-line treatment for infection with Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis. However, it is not recommended for the empiric treatment of urethritis because of gonococcal antibiotic resistance. Primary syphilis typically manifests with nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy and a chancre, a painless, genital ulcer with indurated borders. Thick, purulent urethral discharge is not typically seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral cefixime and doxycycline in a single dose is an alternative regimen for empiric treatment of urethritis. However, this combination is not a first-line treatment because the drugs are lower efficacy and face increasing gonococcal antimicrobial resistance. Moreover, doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy because it has a harmful impact on fetal skeletal development.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is a second-line treatment option for confirmed infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Genitourinary Chlamydia infection can manifest with dysuria and urethral discharge in a sexually active patient. However, this patient's urinalysis indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, for which erythromycin is not a recommended treatment. Moreover, studies have reported cardiovascular and urinary malformations after exposure to erythromycin in pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin was formerly used to treat Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. However, this therapy is no longer recommended because of increasing rates of drug resistance. Oral azithromycin is a first-line treatment option for confirmed chlamydial urethritis.

F) CORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is used to treat urethritis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This drug is safe to use during pregnancy. Combination therapy is only recommended if coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not yet been excluded. In such cases, ceftriaxone should be combined with azithromycin (in pregnant patients) or doxycycline (in nonpregnant adults). Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to avoid reinfection.

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for C. trachomatis is always warranted to assess for coinfection, and screening for HIV infection should be performed. NAAT for N. gonorrhea should be done 3 months after completion of therapy because of the risk of reinfection.
questions.hint: A thick, purulent urethral discharge that shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain indicates a diagnosis of gonorrhea. Risk factors for this condition include unprotected sexual intercourse and multiple sexual partners.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful lesion on his penis. The lesion appeared 2 days ago and has since grown in size. It is draining yellow purulent material. One week ago, he returned from a 1-month trip to Cambodia. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, or L3 causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV initially manifests with small, painless, shallow genital ulcers that heal spontaneously without scarring. Approx. 2–6 weeks later, patients develop painful suppurative lymphadenopathy that may ulcerate (buboes) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, and chills). This patient's acutely painful lesion, lymphadenopathy, and absence of systemic signs are not characteristic of LGV.
Image Description:

A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).

This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate into large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily. Regional lymphadenopathy is usually absent. This patient's acutely painful ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy make infection with K. granulomatis unlikely.
Image Description:

Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which manifests with a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders (a chancre) and bilateral painless regional lymphadenopathy. This patient's painful ulcer, tender regional lymphadenopathy, and purulent exudate make infection with T. pallidum unlikely.
Image Description:

Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with HSV (typically HSV2) causes genital herpes, which manifests with painful lymphadenopathy with multiple grouped painful vesicles and/or ulcers on or around the genitals. Patients also experience severe genital discomfort (e.g., itching and burning) and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise). This patient's solitary ulcer, purulent exudate, and lack of vesicles make HSV infection unlikely.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

E) CORRECT:

Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which typically manifests with an intensely painful, clearly demarcated lesion with a grey necrotic base and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Men usually present with a single lesion, while women often develop multiple synchronous lesions. H. ducreyi is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Cambodia) and rare in the United States. Chancroid is usually treated with a single dose of oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

F) INCORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea, which is usually asymptomatic but can manifest with urethritis or epididymitis in men. Urethritis manifests with painful urination and spontaneous mucopurulent discharge from the urethral meatus, while epididymitis manifests with acute, painful, unilateral scrotal swelling. None of these symptoms are present in this patient. In addition, N. gonorrhoeae infection does not explain this patient's painful exudative ulcer or tender lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: This patient's painful and necrotic lesion with purulent discharge as well as tender lymphadenopathy following recent travel to a tropical region (i.e., Cambodia) is suggestive of chancroid.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of lesions on her vulva. She has no pain or discharge from the lesions but she has noticed some bloody spots in her underwear. For the past year, she has been traveling around India, Australia, South Africa, and the Caribbean while working as a blogger. During this time, she has had unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. Examination shows 4 nontender indurated ulcers on her labia minora that have a red base and raised, rolled margins; the ulcers are up to 8 mm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A Giemsa-stained smear of one of the ulcers shows oval bodies within macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A syphilitic chancre (caused by Treponema pallidum) manifests as indurated nontender genital ulceration, which is seen here. However, it typically manifests as a single ulcer rather than multiple ulcers and is associated with nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Moreover, a smear of the ulcer would show extracellular spirochetes rather than the intracellular inclusion bodies seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes (caused by herpes simplex virus, particularly HSV-2) often manifests as multiple genital ulcers with a red base, like the ones seen here, and a Giemsa-stained smear of the ulcers may show intranuclear bodies (Cowdry A inclusions). However, the ulcers would be painful, nonindurated, have flat margins with an erythematous halo, and be accompanied by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, unlike the lesions seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

C) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum (caused by L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis) can manifest as painless genital ulceration without inguinal lymphadenopathy because the tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy that is characteristic of this condition occurs 2–6 weeks after genital ulceration. Moreover, a Giemsa-stained smear of the ulcer may show intracytoplasmic bodies (reticulate bodies). However, this condition typically causes a single small, shallow, nonindurated ulcer that resolves within a few days whereas this patient has had multiple indurated lesions for the past three weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Chancroid (caused by Haemophilus ducreyi) can manifest as multiple vulvar ulcers, which are seen in this patient. However, these ulcers are typically very painful, nonindurated, and have undermined margins with a grey or yellow purulent base, unlike the lesions seen here. In addition, chancroid is typically accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have, and a smear of the ulcer would show extracellular chains of coccobacilli rather than intracellular inclusions.

E) CORRECT:

Multiple, painless, indurated genital ulcers with a vascular beefy-red base and elevated, rolled margins along with the absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy suggest granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a pathogen that is endemic to tropical and subtropical regions. The lesions begin as nodules at the site of inoculation after a highly variable incubation period (median of 50 days) before ulcerating. This infection is treated with azithromycin, or, alternatively, doxycycline.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.
questions.hint: This patient with high-risk sexual behavior has a sexually transmitted infection caused by a gram-negative, obligate intracellular coccobacillus that multiplies in mononuclear cells (e.g., macrophages) and forms bipolar intracytoplasmic inclusions called Donovan bodies.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Perform nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This woman meets the criteria identified by the USPSTF for the screening of a condition that is common among individuals in her age group and should receive testing at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

In asymptomatic patients, urine culture is only recommended by the USPSTF for the screening of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant individuals. Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not usually result in symptomatic infection, so the USPSTF recommends against this screening in nonpregnant adults. Screening may result in overtreatment, increasing the risk of patients developing adverse effects from antibiotic therapy and raising the risk of emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum CA-125 concentration can be used in the evaluation of a patient with an adnexal mass or to monitor disease progression or recurrence of treatment in patients with ovarian cancer. Although this patient has a first-degree relative with ovarian cancer, which thereby increases her risk of developing ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 concentration measurement is not recommended for screening of ovarian cancer in asymptomatic patients. Patients with a high-risk family history should rather be referred to genetic counseling.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening with high-risk HPV testing (hrHPV test) every 5 years in all women > 30 years of age; the American Cancer Society recommends primary HPV testing every 5 years for women 25–65 years of age. In young women, HPV infections tend to be transient and resolve without treatment, and testing in this age group results in a considerable false-positive rate, which can lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, the USPSTF recommends against cervical cancer screening as the harms outweigh the benefits.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and in women ≥ 25 years of age with specific risk factors (e.g., women with new or multiple sex partners). N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections are often asymptomatic in women but can result in complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility. Screening consists of nucleic acid amplification tests of the urine, which have both high sensitivity and specificity for these infections. Although there is not a defined screening interval, it is reasonable to annually repeat the screening in women with new or persistent risk factors.

F) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening by PAP smear every 3 years for all women between 21 and 65 years of age. In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, cervical cancer is rare and screening might result in false-positive results, which may lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). Some of these procedures increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm delivery). Because evidence shows that the harms of cervical cancer screening in women younger than 21 years of age outweigh the benefits, the USPSTF recommends against screening in this age group.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for a condition that is common in sexually active women < 25 years of age.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a genital lesion that she first noticed 3 days ago. There is no pain or pruritus and the patient has had no vaginal discharge. Six months ago, she had a lower urinary tract infection that was treated with oral nitrofurantoin. She is sexually active with a new male partner, whom she met 2 weeks ago. She has an intrauterine device and uses condoms consistently. She has no history of serious illness or allergies and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. A photograph of the vulva is shown. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin is the preferred treatment for granuloma inguinale, which can manifest with painless genital ulcers. However, granuloma inguinale ulcers have rolled granulomatous borders, continuously enlarge, bleed easily, and are described as “beefy-red.” In addition, the causal pathogen is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries; granuloma inguinale is uncommon in the US.
Image Description:

Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for chancroid, which can manifest with well-circumscribed genital ulcers. However, patients usually develop painful, erythematous ulcers with a necrotic base and purulent exudate, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders. Additionally, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and abscess formation, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

C) CORRECT:

Although consistent use of barrier contraception significantly lowers the risk of infection with syphilis, it can still be transmitted via skin-to-skin contact with an active lesion (e.g., base of the penis, oral cavity). A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G is the first-line treatment for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis. Doxycycline or ceftriaxone can be administered to patients who are allergic to penicillin. Patients should also be counseled on the risk of a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, which is an acute, self-limiting (< 1 day), systemic reaction to bacterial endotoxins and pyrogens that are released after the initiation of antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the preferred treatment for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which can manifest with painless genital ulcers during the primary phase of infection. However, most affected individuals present with multiple small, herpetiform lesions, rather than a single well-circumscribed ulcer with indurated borders. In addition, LGV is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is the preferred treatment for herpes simplex virus infection, which can manifest with genital lesions. However, affected individuals typically present with grouped painful vesicles on an erythematous base, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.
questions.hint: A painless, well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesion with indurated borders in a patient with a new sexual partner should raise concern for a chancre.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Completing the immunization schedule (via catch-up immunization) protects against vaccine-preventable diseases such as diphtheria and HPV infection. Diphtheria manifests acutely with sore throat, malaise, fever, pseudomembranous pharyngitis, and painful lymphadenopathy. Oral HPV infection manifests with warts or oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer (SCC). Oropharyngeal SCC can result in a nontender ulcerative lesion and painless cervical lymphadenopathy, but there is no evidence of a malignancy on this patient's lymph node biopsy. There is currently no immunization available against this patient's infection.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is at increased risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection (STI) because he has multiple partners. His nontender oral ulcer with raised, indurated borders (chancre) and concomitant nontender lymphadenopathy (due to reactive follicular hyperplasia) is consistent with primary syphilis. The chancre is usually solitary, and develops at the site of inoculation after about 3 weeks. The chancre resolves without scarring after 3–6 weeks regardless of treatment. While primary syphilitic lesions most often occur in the genital region, about 5–10% of cases of primary syphilis are extragenital. Typical localizations are the oral cavity, hands and fingers, or the anus and perianal region, which reflect sexual practices, but chancres can occur wherever the skin has been in contact with Treponema pallidum from infectious sores. The use of a condom during vaginal or anal sex, and a dental dam during oral sex, can protect an individual against STIs by preventing contact with body fluids or an infectious lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Smoking is one of the most important risk factors for head and neck cancers, and a nontender, ulcerative lesion with concomitant nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is also consistent with malignancy. However, fine-needle aspiration cytology shows no signs of malignancy (e.g., keratin pearls in squamous cell carcinoma, the most common mucosal head and neck cancer); reactive follicular hyperplasia suggests another etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary restriction of gluten is used to prevent manifestations of celiac disease (CD), which is caused by a maladaptive immune response to this protein. CD can lead to oral lesions as a result of malabsorption and nutrient deficiency. However, the oral manifestations of CD are poor dentition, atrophic glossitis, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, and cheilitis. The appearance of this patient's oral ulcer, its painless nature, and the concomitant cervical lymphadenopathy are inconsistent with any of the oral manifestations of CD. Moreover, this patient does not have signs typically seen in CD, such as chronic diarrhea, recurrent abdominal pain, and signs of malabsorption such as weight loss, fatigue, or anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can cause oral ulceration and lymphadenopathy. However, HSV infection typically causes multiple, shallow ulcers with flat margins, and both the ulcerations and lymphadenopathy would be painful. Furthermore, herpes infections are prone to recurrence even with acyclovir therapy; previous acyclovir therapy would not have prevented a new episode. Acyclovir only decreases the duration and severity of an active episode and reduces viral shedding during the episode.
questions.hint: If this patient had a rapid plasma reagin test, it would likely be positive.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of a urethral discharge and painful urination. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are metformin and amlodipine. He is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife and does not use condoms. He reports that his wife does not have similar symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Genital examination shows purulent discharge from the urethral meatus. There is no scrotal swelling or tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Nucleic acid amplification testing of urethral discharge is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and negative for Chlamydia trachomatis. The results of a screening test for HIV and a rapid plasma reagin test are negative. The physician counsels the patient on the need to return for a follow-up visit and bring his wife into the office for testing. The patient says that it is difficult for them to take time off from work, and they can only come for a visit in several weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient only
Oral cefixime for the patient and his wife
Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime for his wife
Oral doxycycline for the patient and his wife
Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime and doxycycline for his wife

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea, sexual partners, such as this patient's wife, should also receive treatment. EPT is recommended for all sexual partners of the patient from the past 60 days to treat the infection and avoid reinfections.

B) INCORRECT:

Although oral cefixime can be used as an alternative regimen to treat individuals with gonorrhea and their sexual partners, this therapy has limited efficacy and should only be considered if first-line treatment is unavailable.

C) CORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea of the cervix, urethra, rectum, and pharynx in patients in whom concurrent chlamydia infection has been excluded. To prevent reinfections, the CDC recommends that all sexual partners from the past 60 days be evaluated and treated with the same regimen as the patient. If sexual partners cannot be evaluated in a timely manner, EPT with a single dose of oral cefixime is recommended. Oral doxycycline should be added to the treatment if chlamydia infection has not been excluded in the index patient. In addition to EPT, sexual partners should be provided with written information on gonorrhea, its treatment, and adverse effects of medication. They should also be advised to seek medical evaluation if symptoms or adverse events occur.

EPT is legally allowed in most states, although under varying conditions. There is no state that prohibits EPT.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for C. trachomatis infection, which can manifest with urethral discharge and dysuria. However, this patient tested positive only for N. gonorrhea, which is not treated with doxycycline.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea. Dual therapy with both oral cefixime and doxycycline is indicated for sexual partners if coinfection with chlamydia is either suspected or cannot be ruled out in the index patient. However, because the index patient is negative for C. trachomatis, dual therapy is unnecessary.
questions.hint: Expedited partner therapy (EPT) is indicated for certain sexually transmitted infections (STI).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female college student reports being sexually assaulted 48 hours ago by a man she met at a party. She recalls forced vaginal penetration and does not believe the assailant used a condom. She states that she does not have bleeding, vaginal discharge, severe pain, or other trauma.
She currently takes oral contraceptives and has no known drug allergies. She has received the complete hepatitis B vaccination series (and is known to be immune) and has also received the human papillomavirus vaccination series.
In addition to referral to a local rape crisis center and counseling on HIV postexposure prophylaxis, which one of the following empiric treatment regimens for sexually transmitted infections should be offered to this woman?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin would not provide activity against Trichomonas; in addition, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin for empiric treatment in patients in whom gonococcal infection has not been ruled out, because of concerns about increasing azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

B) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for syphilis or herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, neither benzathine penicillin nor acyclovir is warranted in this case. Syphilis is less prevalent than other sexually transmitted infections, and prophylaxis against gonorrhea may also have activity against Treponema pallidum.

C) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for syphilis or herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, neither benzathine penicillin nor acyclovir is warranted in this case. Syphilis is less prevalent than other sexually transmitted infections, and prophylaxis against gonorrhea may also have activity against Treponema pallidum. In addition, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin for empiric treatment in patients in whom gonococcal infection has not been ruled out, because of concerns about increasing azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

D) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines do not recommend empiric treatment for herpes simplex virus infection in people who have been sexually assaulted; consequently, acyclovir is not warranted in this case.

E) CORRECT:

The lifetime prevalence of sexual assault is between 13% and 39% for women; college students and those younger than age 24 are at increased risk. Between 17% and 43% of women who have been sexually assaulted present for medical evaluation after the assault.

The most frequently diagnosed sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in women after sexual assault are trichomoniasis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia. Patients may not have symptoms of these STIs soon after the assault, and testing can yield false-negative results. Therefore, all patients should be offered prophylaxis for these STIs. The combination of ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and doxycycline will treat gonorrhea, trichomoniasis, and chlamydia, respectively.

Current guidelines also recommend the following for women who have been sexually assaulted:

• Hepatitis B vaccination if the patient is not already immunized against hepatitis B virus or is not immune to this infection; hepatitis B immune globulin should also be considered if the patient is unvaccinated and the assailant is known to have hepatitis B infection
• Human papillomavirus vaccination for women aged 9 to 26 years who have not yet been vaccinated (this can be considered up to age 45 based on shared decision-making)
• Levonorgestrel for pregnancy prevention
• Discussion of HIV postexposure prophylaxis

Key learning point: Women who present after forced vaginal penetration should be offered prophylactic antibiotic treatment against infection from Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia, and Trichomonas.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is evaluated for penile ulcers that developed one week ago, during a trip to the Caribbean. He initially noticed “red pimples” on his penis that then became painful ulcers. A few days later, he noticed a tender lump in his groin. He reports that during the trip, he had vaginal intercourse with sex workers and did not use condoms.
On examination, his vital signs are normal. There are several ragged-appearing, non-indurated, 1-cm ulcers over the shaft of the penis that bleed easily. A large and exquisitely tender lymph node is present over the right groin.
Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely etiologic agent in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which usually manifests as painless, destructive, beefy-red, and highly vascular ulcerative lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

HSV causes painful ulcers that are usually shallow and vesicular and can be recurrent, but it is less typically associated with suppurative inguinal adenopathy than the most likely causal organism of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis; the primary chancre is typically painless and indurated. Secondary syphilis typically causes a diffuse rash involving the hands and soles and condyloma latum (flat, broad, whitish, wart-like lesions) on mucous membranes.

D) CORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is characterized by deep, painful, ragged-appearing penile ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal adenopathy. The ulcer associated with H. ducreyi begins as a tender, elevated bump or papule that becomes a pus-filled, open sore with eroded or ragged edges.

H. ducreyi is a significant cause of genital ulcer disease in parts of Africa and the Caribbean. Identification of the organism on special culture media is required for a definitive diagnosis. A probable diagnosis can be made if a patient has a typical clinical presentation (including one or more painful genital ulcers, as described in this patient), is found to have no evidence of Treponema pallidum infection on dark-field microscopy of the ulcer exudate or by serologic testing, and has a negative test for HSV performed on the ulcer exudate. See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.

Key learning point: Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi is characteristically associated with painful, ragged-appearing genital ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis L-serovars causes lymphogranuloma venereum, which is characterized by short-lived, painless genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female college student wants to discuss long-acting, reversible contraception. She became sexually active 6 months ago and has had one sexual partner; they use condoms for contraception only intermittently. She has received the human papillomavirus vaccination. She is asymptomatic, in good health, and has no medical or surgical problems. Her physical examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following infections should this patient be tested for?

choices.text: Gonorrhea, hepatitis B virus, and HIV
Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and hepatitis B virus
Chlamydia, gonorrhea, hepatitis B virus, and HIV

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV screening is recommended for all people at least once in their lives, regardless of reported risks. This is particularly relevant in someone who is sexually active, where more-frequent screening may be indicated. The CDC recommends one-time screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥18 years old. However, screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea is also recommended in sexually active females 25 years of age or younger.

B) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends routine screening for Neisseria gonorrhoeae in all sexually active females 25 years of age or younger. HIV screening is recommended for all people at least once in their lives, regardless of reported risks. This is particularly relevant in someone who is sexually active, where more-frequent screening may be indicated. The CDC recommends one-time screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥18 years old. However, screening for chlamydia is also recommended in sexually active females 25 years of age or younger.

C) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends routine screening for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in all sexually active females 25 years of age or younger. The CDC recommends one-time screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥18 years old. However, HIV screening also is recommended for all people at least once in their lives, regardless of reported risks. This is particularly relevant in someone who is sexually active, where more-frequent screening may be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends routine screening for Chlamydia trachomatis in all sexually active females 25 years of age or younger. HIV screening is recommended for all people at least once in their lives, regardless of reported risks. This is particularly relevant in someone who is sexually active, where more-frequent screening may be indicated. However, screening for gonorrhea and hepatitis B virus is also recommended in sexually active females 25 years of age or younger and in all individuals ≥18 years old, respectively.

E) CORRECT:

Approximately 26 million new sexually transmitted infections (STIs) occur per year in the United States, and almost half occur among young people ages 15 to 24. When STIs are treated late or left untreated, they can have major physical and psychological consequences, including chronic pain, infertility, and possible death. Many people with chlamydia, gonorrhea, or HIV infection are initially asymptomatic.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends routine screening for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in all sexually active females 25 years of age or younger.

HIV screening is recommended for all people at least once in their lives, regardless of reported risks. This is particularly relevant in someone who is sexually active, for whom more frequent screening may be indicated.

The CDC recommends one-time screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥18 years old. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends HBV screening for a narrower group of people, namely pregnant women and people at increased risk for HBV infection. People at increased risk for HBV infection include those born in countries with a high prevalence of HBV infection (≥2%), people with HIV, people who inject drugs, men who have sex with men, people who are immunosuppressed or receiving hemodialysis, and household contacts of people with HBV infection.

Screening for syphilis, trichomoniasis, bacterial vaginitis, herpes simplex virus, human papillomavirus, and hepatitis A virus is not routinely recommended in asymptomatic, nonpregnant female adolescents.

Key learning point: Sexually active women younger than 25 years of age should be screened for the following sexually transmitted infections: chlamydia, gonorrhea, and HIV. All individuals ≥18 years of age should receive one-time screening for hepatitis B virus infection.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman who identifies as a lesbian asks for suggestions on safe sex practices. She reports no illicit or prescription drug use but states that she smokes 10 cigarettes per day and occasionally drinks alcohol. She reached menarche at age 12 and has regular monthly periods. Her last menstrual period was 4 days ago.
She became sexually active at age 13 and has had several casual female partners. She engages in cunnilingus and in anal and vaginal sex using sex toys. Her last sexual encounter was 2 weeks ago. She has never had sexual contact with a male.
Physical examination and vital signs are within normal limits.
Which one of the following recommendations for preventing sexually transmitted infections is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend that sex toys be lubricated with spermicide before anal penetration
Encourage routine use of antiretroviral preexposure prophylaxis before anal play with toys
Recommend manual vaginal stimulation instead of using a dildo
Encourage careful washing of sex toys after each use
Recommend genital scissoring (rubbing the vulva against the partner's for stimulation) rather than cunnilingus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonspermicidal, rather than spermicidal, lubricants should be used during anal penetration because N-9 spermicide may increase the risk for STI transmission by irritating the rectal epithelial cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Preexposure antiretroviral prophylaxis has been studied for a wide variety of people — including men who have sex with men, heterosexuals who have partners with HIV, and heterosexuals in areas of high HIV prevalence — but it is not yet approved for exclusively lesbian partners. The rate of HIV transmission between HIV-discordant lesbian couples is thought to be low.

C) INCORRECT:

Manual vaginal stimulation and vaginal fisting (inserting four or more digits into the vagina) can increase the risk for vaginal tearing, which increases transmission rates for STIs from contact with the partner’s hands and nails.

D) CORRECT:

Women who have sex with women are at risk for bacterial, viral, and protozoal sexually transmitted infections (STIs), but they do not reliably receive adequate counseling about risk-reduction behaviors.
